comments.text:
The dictionary-correct plural is "octopuses." While "octopi" has become 
colloquially acceptable, it's incorrect as far as language roots go. 
The "i" ending for plurals is for Latin words. "Octopus" comes from a Greek 
base, making "octopodes" the /technically/ correct plural. However, it's 
very rarely, if ever, used. 

"Octopuses" is, for all intents and purposes, correct.
comments.author: SpiritusPolypus

comments.text:
+Brian Fagioli both "octopi" and "octopodes" exist (for Latin vs Greek 
plural forms respectively), and both are equally wrong, but you can use 
them if you want to.

From a "hipsterism" standpoint (ie "I'm so educated that I try to change 
words according to the source language") the latinized version is arguably 
technically even more wrong than the Greek one, since the origin is 
arguably much more Greek than Latin (but let's face it, the Romans happily 
stole all Greek culture, and a lot of it came *through* latin).

At the same time, from an actual usage standpoint, "octopi" is actually 
more correct than "octopodes" just by virtue of being more common (and 
actually predates the Greekified version: the Latinizing hipsters are 
original, and the Greekifying hipsters just tried to out-do the hipsterism 
of the former ones).
comments.author: Linus Torvalds

comments.author: Lars Hanisch

comments.text: +Linus Torvalds I thought it was Octopi...
comments.author: Brian Fagioli

comments.text:
Another true fact about octopuses: the preferential plural form is in fact 
the English-sounding "octopuses", not the Greek "octopodes" or (even worse) 
the pseudo-Latin "octopi".

You wouldn't call platypuses "platypodes" either. Or call multiple 
semicolon characters "semicola". Or, for that matter, make the plural for 
of "hound" be "hounde" just because it has Germanic origin.

Pretty much all English words come from another language, and the belief 
that just because a word has roots in some other language it should be 
treated as a foreign word is just misplaced hipsterism.

So repeat after me: "I love octopuses"
comments.author: Linus Torvalds

comments.text:
The Law of Gravitation is a law because can be mathematically defined 
(F=Gm1m2/r^2) - note that the law of gravitation and the theory of gravity 
(aka general theory of relativity) are two different things; one models 
what would happen, the other explains why it happens. The theory of 
evolution through natural selection is a theory because it is a broad 
explanation (that has been consistently upheld by evidence) of how 
evolution takes place.

comments.text:
+D Max You're confusing theory with scientific theory. As HugoLuman says, 
what you call a theory is called a hypothesis in science.

Cells, germs, atoms, gravity, plate tectonics, evolution, etc. are all 
facts that described by "theories." If you think "germ theory" is just a 
"theory," then take a live pathogen and mix it into your bloodstream. A 
scientific theory is a consistently proven explanation of how nature works 
(in fact, i think it might be better to refer to the "theory of evolution" 
as the "theory of evolution through natural selection"). We know evolution 
happens. The theory describes HOW it happens. Generally, a scientific 
theory is understood as scientific fact.

Long time ago, actually. Because the word derives from Greek ("okto," 
meaning eight [becomes "octa"], plus "pod," meaning foot [becomes "pous," 
then "pus"] and not Latin, many linguists say that "octopi," which carries 
the Latin plural ending, is incorrect and use "octopuses" instead. And 
"octupuses" is a lot funnier than "octopi."

Sadly it's terribly irregular, though. For example, no one would say viri 
instead of viruses, and for cactus both cacti and cactuses are considered

comments.text:
"Octopi" comes from people falsely (though understandably) assuming octopus 
is Latin. (It comes from Greek.) Lots of words borrowed from Latin have 
irregular plurals in English, such as fungus ⇒ fungi, nucleus ⇒ nuclei, 
millennium ⇒ millennia, matrix ⇒ matrices, etc. And the -us ⇒ -i 
pluralization rule is probably best known.

top_comment.author: Joe R

comments.text:
Apparently our friend thought your simple compliment was much more than 
that! He's probably revolting against the growing tendency towards 
hyperbole in American usage. You know what I mean ... the situation where 
what would otherwise be a simple compliment (e.g., A modest "thumb's-up") 
becomes "It is the absolute best in the universe and nothing comes even 
close!!!" (with more and more exclamation points each year as if 
punctuation were subject to the same rate of inflation that affects the 
value of the U.S. dollar!!!!!!!!!!!). The danger in this tendency is that 
you leave yourself with no room for gradients of praise, and thus the 
praise becomes less reliable and loses its effectiveness if everything a 
person takes a fancy to (from things you think are just okay to your 
favorite things) is lumped together in a one-size-fits-all description 
(e.g., "the best."). Joe R, I am proud to spell and capitalize your YT 
handle properly, and I'm thankful that you unwittingly provided an 
opportunity for so many of us to learn and grow.  Keep those comments 
coming.
comments.author: David W. Floren

comments.text:
I'm flattered that both of you would devote so much time discussing what 
was nothing more than a simple compliment to the channel.
comments.author: Joe R

comments.text:
+Calemvir Reaper Your response is well taken!  Just goes to show not 
everything has been "dumbed-down" in a venue where ignorance can be the 
common currency.  I too fall into the vanilla ice cream camp, so we should 
have no problems on that particular (ice-cream) score!  As an aside, I 
enjoy mentioning "ice cream" in the text of my responses, as it serves 
largely to please the audience (as many other scrumptious food-related 
references do) by stimulating the audience's appetite, in a very literal 
sense.  Regarding what you might think as a disconnect between my 
abbreviation of YouTube and my full spelling of commentator "Joe R's" YT 
handle, my modus operandi is to offer greater respect to human individuals 
(e.g., recognizing their names) than to the more abstract and less personal 
"corporate persons" (as the U.S. Supreme Court in Citizens United vs. 
F.E.C. like to think of them) (e.g., YouTube).  P.S.,  I still love you, 
YT!  P.P.S., I believe Joe R's qualifier "easily" was meant to do nothing 
more than reinforce the unassailability of his not-to-be-contested personal 
opinion.  He might as well have typed, "This is my favorite YT channel, and 
no one can convince me otherwise."  Basically, a conversation-ender.
comments.author: David W. Floren

comments.text:
+David W. Floren I have never implied nor am I ever planning to critizise 
every commenter on Youtube, nor do I feel the need to express my
